ygData.messageBody:
First of all, the paladin's spells are just as likely to be resisted as
ours. I've been rooted and blinded before, and it's very, very difficult to
keep someone under both for any significant period of time. 5 rounds to
"finish off the pet" will be more than sufficient to get out of at least 1,
if not both. An actual problem is that sometimes pets for SKs don't work in
PvP. The important part of the darkness spells is the slowing more than the
damage. Starting a fight with siphon strength, which I've never seen
resisted, does a 20 point switch in strength balance and gives the SK an
advantage in melee. When the fight comes down to melee, which they all
eventually do, the SK is going to deal more damage much more quickly. I do,
however, concede the paladins have bows part.

I have not ever lost to a paladin, and I don't attack anyone who is going to
or has just got their corpse. It's not that I play an honorable character,
as much as respect for another player. My main point to all of this is that
I do not believe SKs are weak, which you agree with at the beginning of your
message to a degree. I also do not believe SKs are significantly more
powerful than paladins, by the same token. I'm saying we have a comparable
level of power, except, perhaps, for HT being resisted.

----- Original Message -----
From: Howard Chan <hchan@...>
To: <eq_shadowknights@onelist.com>
Sent: Sunday, June 27, 1999 9:09 AM
Subject: Re: [eq_shadowknights] LOOK AT THIS VERY IMPORTANT SERIOUS


> From: "Howard Chan" <hchan@...>
>
> Before I continue any further, let me say that I do not believe the SK is
> overly weak. Being a hybrid with downtime equaling a Warrior, obviously,
> seem unfair. But other than the downtime and the useless, class-specific
> skill (HT), I believe that the SK is one of the most interesting class to
> play. In fact, I would go on to say that we can do the most damage out of
> all melee classes in a fight with an NPC (Double Attack + Pet + DoT = mega
> damage). I also believe that it is not too overly important to travel
before
> level 30. For many levels, I have never needed to travel anywhere that
would
> kill me on sight. There are always places to fight up to level 30; at
which
> point, we do actually get Gather Shadows. Now, I will address Mr.
Stovall's
> post:
>
> Scenario 1:
> What is the first DoT that the Shadow Knight would use? Engulfing
Darkness.
> What is the first spell the Paladin would use? Flash of Light. Now, let's
> assume they both go off. No resists, no fizzles, no interruption. The SK
is
> blinded, the Paladin is free to kill the pet. Once the pet is gone,
Paladin
> blinds the Shadow Knight again, repeat until SK is dead.
>
> Scenario 2:
> Let's assume that Engulfing Darkness is casted upon the Paladin. The
Paladin
> would just fight the SK and the pet. The pet's attack = Center + Spirit
> Armor. So, it is basically down to LH versus HT + DoT. And as we all know,
> HT and a 100HP DoT does not compensate for LH.
>
> Scenario 3:
> Let's consider what you said in your scenario. The pet is gone and Paladin
> has taken more damage. Is the Shadow Knight able to get the Paladin down
to
> the point where the HT will defeat the Paladin? No. It might have took 5
> rounds at most to finish off the pet; thus, the Paladin is far from being
> dead (during that time, the Paladin might have lost 200HP at most -
> considering that all the arrows hit and DoT). Once the pet is gone, the
> battle turns over. All the Paladin needs to do is to Blind, Root and Heal.
> That was excluding Center and Spirit Armor.
>
> Personally, I do not see why the Paladin would go for the SK when he/she
> knows that the pet is the main disrupter of spells. In addition, you
failed
> to consider that a Paladin can also have a bow. With the combination
Blind,
> Root, shoot and Heal, the Paladin is always one step ahead of the Shadow
> Knight in fights. Basically, the reason why a Paladin will defeat a SK is
> because of a few simply spells.
>
> As for winning unrigged fights with red-cons, I really find that hard to
> believe. Red-cons would resisted Darkness, Fear and Harm Touch. The Harm
> Touch will not compensate for their LH at that point. Furthermore, at
higher
> levels, they are able to hit more often with higher damage; while taking
> less hits. I can see a Shadow Knight defeating red-con Warriors and Monks.
> However, looking at all the above factors makes me disbelieve that a
Paladin
> can lose to a blue-formidable-con Shadow Knight at best. Perhaps you have
a
> strategy that I do not see? Or perhaps the Paladin was on the way to
> retrieve his/her corpse?
>
>
> >I disagree. I'm on Rallos Zek, PvP. What an SK does while rooted is
fire
> >his bow, send his pet, and stack his DoTs. Fletching is a very, very
> >important ability that usually gets overlooked.
> >
> >In the same scenario the SK have a 30+ damage bow. He gets rooted,
starts
> >firing arrows. The pet gets up in the paladin's face - good for
> disruption.
> >The paladin has 2 choices. Deal with the SK or deal with the pet. If he
> >deals with the pet, obviously the SK will tear the crap out of him. So
> >he'll attack the SK. While he's trying to blind, he gets hit with an
> arrow,
> >bashed by a pet, etc which has a good chance of spell disruption, and
gets
> >Engulfed in darkness. If he gets the blind, he'll probably waste the pet
> >while your blinded. By the time the root's over, the paladin notices he
> has
> >taken more damage, and is currently slowed with a pissed off SK in his
> face.
> >
> >These kinds of things won't work you say? I've never lost a fight with a
> >paladin, even yellow and red ones.
>
